Identification.LongTitle: Criminal Procedure Rules of the Court of Queen’s Bench of New Brunswick

Provision.Text: The Court of Queen’s Bench of New Brunswick, under subsections 482(1) and (3) of the Criminal Code, with the concurrence of a majority of the judges thereof present at a meeting held on September 5, 2014, makes the following Criminal Procedure Rules of the Court of Queen’s Bench of New Brunswick numbered 1 to 12, that are to come into effect upon publication in the Canada Gazette as required by subsection 482(4) of the Criminal Code.

SignatureTitle.Emphasis: Chief Justice of the Court of Queen’s Bench of New Brunswick

Heading.TitleText: Rule 1 - Definitions, Application, Interpretation, and Forms

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these Rules.

Definition.Text: Application means a proceeding commenced by Notice of Application whether described in the enabling legislation or another authority as an application or a motion. (requête)
Clerk’s office means the office of the Clerk of the Court in the judicial district where the proceeding is to be commenced or is pending or is being heard, as the case may be. (greffe)
Court means the Court of Queen’s Bench of New Brunswick and includes a judge. (Cour)
judge means a Justice of the Court. (juge)

Section.Text: These Rules apply to all criminal proceedings within the jurisdiction of the Court.

Subsection.Text: These Rules are intended to provide for the just determination of every criminal proceeding, and shall be liberally construed to secure simplicity and uniformity in procedure, fairness in administration, the elimination of unjustifiable expense and the avoidance of delay.
Where a matter is not provided for in the Criminal Code or these Rules, the procedure shall be as specified by the Court or determined by reference to the Rules of Court of New Brunswick.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise indicated, where an accused is not represented by counsel but acts in person, anything that these Rules require counsel to do shall be done by the accused and anything that these Rules permit counsel to do may be done by the accused.

TitleText.Emphasis: Application of the Criminal Code Provisions

Section.Text: The interpretation sections of the Criminal Code apply to these Rules.

The Chief Justice of the Court of Queen’s Bench of New Brunswick may from time to time issue practice notes not inconsistent with these Rules and such practice notes shall apply to the same extent as these Rules.
The forms prescribed in the attached Appendix of Forms shall be used where applicable and with such variations as the circumstances require.

TitleText.Emphasis: Effect of Non-compliance with the Rules

Section.Text: A failure to comply with these Rules is an irregularity and does not render a proceeding or a step, document or order in a proceeding a nullity, and the Court:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: may grant all necessary amendments or other relief in accordance with Rule 2.02, on such terms as are just, to secure the just determination of the real matters in dispute or,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: only where and as necessary in the interests of justice, may set aside the proceeding or a step, document or order in the proceeding in whole or in part.

Subsection.Text: The Court may, only where and as necessary in the interests of justice:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: dispense with compliance with any rule at any time or substitute a process that would produce an equally just result,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: extend or abridge any time requirements prescribed by these Rules on such terms as are just.

Subsection.Text: An order extending time may be made before or after the expiration of the time prescribed.

Section.Text: Every document in a proceeding shall be printed, typewritten, or reproduced legibly on good quality paper.
Every document in a proceeding shall contain:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the Court, judicial district and the court file number;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the style of the proceeding in accordance with Form 1 (Notice of Application), but in a document other than a record, order or report, where there are more than two parties to the proceeding, a short title showing the names of the first party on each side followed by the words “and others” may be used;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: its date;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address and telephone number of counsel filing the document or, where a party is not represented by counsel, the name of the party, address for service and telephone number and, where available, that party’s e-mail address and facsimile transmission (fax) number.

Section.Text: At the request of a person entitled to see and to receive a copy of a document in a court file, a certified copy of the document shall be delivered upon payment of any prescribed fee.
Where these Rules require notice to be given, it shall be given in writing.

Subsection.Text: All documents required to be filed in a proceeding shall be filed in the Clerk’s office, except where they are filed in the course of a hearing or where these Rules provide otherwise.
An affidavit, transcript, record or brief to be used on the hearing of an Application shall be filed in the Clerk’s office.

Heading.TitleText: Filing by Leaving in Clerk’s Office or by Mail

Subsection.Text: A document may be filed by leaving it at or mailing it to the Clerk’s office.

Heading.TitleText: Date of Filing Where Filed by Mail

Subsection.Text: Where a document is filed by mail, the date of the filing stamp of the Clerk’s office on the document shall be deemed to be the date of its filing.

Heading.TitleText: Where Document Filed by Mail Not Received

Subsection.Text: Where a Clerk’s office has no record of the receipt of a document alleged to have been filed by mail, the document shall be deemed not to have been filed.

An affidavit shall be confined to a statement of facts within the personal knowledge of the deponent or to other evidence that the deponent could give if testifying as a witness in court; but the affidavit may contain statements as to information and belief of the deponent with respect to facts which are not contentious, if the source of the deponent’s information and belief therein are specified in the affidavit.
Where these Rules require an affidavit to be made by a party and the party is a corporation, the affidavit may be made for the corporation by an officer, director, or employee of the corporation.

TitleText.Emphasis: General Rules for Manner of Service

Heading.TitleText: Notices of Application and Other Documents

Subsection.Text: A Notice of Application or other document may be served personally, or by an alternative to personal service set out herein, unless these Rules or an order of the Court otherwise specifies.
Any document that is not required to be served personally or by an alternative to personal service

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be served on a party who has counsel of record by serving counsel in a manner provided in Rule 4.03 (2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may be served on a party not represented by counsel or on a person who is not a party,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by mailing a copy of the document to the last address for service provided by the party or person or, if no such address has been provided, to the party’s or person’s last known address together with an Acknowledgment of Receipt Card set out in Form 3A, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: by personal service or by an alternative to personal service.

Subsection.Text: Where a document is to be served personally, the service shall be made

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on an individual, by leaving a copy of the document with the individual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on any corporation, by leaving a copy of the document with an officer, director or agent of the corporation, or with a person at any place of business of the corporation who appears to be in control or management of the place of business;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on the Attorney General of Canada, by leaving a copy of the document with an employee at the office of the Crown Prosecutor retained by the Attorney General of Canada having carriage of the proceedings, or by means of telephone transmission of a facsimile of the document in accordance with Rule 4.03 (3); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: on the Attorney General of New Brunswick, by leaving a copy of the document with an employee at the office of the Crown Prosecutor having carriage of the proceedings, or by means of telephone transmission of a facsimile of the document in accordance with Rule 4.03 (3).

Subsection.Text: A person effecting personal service of a document need not produce the original document or have it in his or her possession.
Where these Rules or an order of the Court permit service by an alternative to personal service, service shall be made in accordance with this Rule.

Service on a party who has counsel may be made by leaving a copy of the document with counsel, or an employee in counsel’s office, but service under this Rule is effective only if counsel or the said employee endorses on the document or a copy of it an acceptance of service and the date of acceptance.
Service of a document on counsel of a party may be made by telephone transmission of a facsimile of the document in accordance with Rule 4.03 (4).
A document that is served by telephone transmission shall include a cover page indicating the

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sender’s name, address and telephone number;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: name of counsel to be served;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: date and time of transmission;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: total number of pages transmitted, including the cover page;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: telephone number from which the document is transmitted; and name and telephone number of a person to contact in the event of transmission problems;

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and shall include an acknowledgement of receipt card in Form 3B; but service under this Rule shall be considered effective only if counsel endorses the acknowledgement of receipt card and returns it to the serving party.

Subsection.Text: A document may be served electronically on a party who has counsel by transmitting the document by electronic mail, but service under this Rule shall be considered effective only if counsel or a duly authorized employee replies electronically acknowledging receipt of the transmission and of the document.
By accepting service counsel shall be deemed to represent to the Court that counsel has the authority of his or her client to accept service.
Service on an accused who is not represented by counsel must be made by personal service unless the Court:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: approves an alternative method of service; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: dispenses with service.

TitleText.Emphasis: Where Document Does Not Reach Person Served

Section.Text: Even though a person has been served with a document in accordance with these Rules, the person may show on Application to set aside the consequences of default, for an extension of time or in support of a request for an adjournment, that the document

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: did not come to his or her notice; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: came to his or her notice only at some time later than when it was served or is deemed to have been served.

Section.Text: Where a document has been served in a manner other than one authorized by these Rules or an order, the Court may make an order validating the service where the Court is satisfied that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the document came to the notice of the person to be served; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the document was served in such a manner that it would have come to the notice of the person to be served, except for the person’s own attempts to evade service.

Subsection.Text: Service of a document may be proved by an affidavit of the person who served it in Form 4A or 4B as the case may be.
Counsel’s written admission or acceptance of service is sufficient proof of service and need not be verified by affidavit.
Where it appears to the Court that it is impractical for any reason to effect prompt service of a document in accordance with these Rules, the Court may make an order

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for substituted service; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: dispensing with service, if the Court considers it necessary in the interests of justice.

Subsection.Text: Where the Court makes an order for substituted service, it shall specify in the order when service in accordance with the order shall be deemed to be effective.
In any criminal proceeding where an application or motion is authorized by statute or otherwise it shall be commenced by a Notice of Application in Form 1.
A Notice of Application shall be filed with the Clerk’s office.
If it appears that the interest of a third party may be affected by a possible outcome, the applicant shall notify the third party of the Application as though they were a party to the Application.
An applicant may apply ex parte to a judge for directions where there is uncertainty whether anyone not a party to an Application should be served.

Any person interested in a proceeding between other parties may, by leave of the Court, intervene therein upon such terms and conditions and with such rights and privileges as the Court may determine.
Every Notice of Application in Form 1 shall state:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the place and date of hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the precise relief sought;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: with reasonable particularity, the grounds to be argued including reference to any statutory provision or rule to be relied upon;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the documentary, affidavit and other evidence to be used at the hearing of the Application; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether any order is required abridging or extending the time for service or filing of the Notice of Application or supporting materials required under these Rules.

Subsection.Text: The Notice of Application shall be served on all parties to the proceeding together with all supporting evidence.

Where, at any point, it appears that a third party not a party to the proceedings has an interest in the possible outcome of an Application that is worthy of protection, the Court shall order the third party be served and given opportunity to be joined to the proceeding.

Except where otherwise expressly provided by the Criminal Code or these Rules, the Notice of Application shall be served and filed with the Court at least 45 days before the date of the hearing of the Application or the date set for trial, which ever date comes first.

Heading.TitleText: Documents May be Filed as Part of Record

Subsection.Text: Any documents served by a party for use on an Application may be filed, together with proof of service, as part of the party’s application record and need not be filed separately if the record is filed within the time prescribed for filing the notice or other material.

A party who intends to refer to a transcript of evidence at the hearing of an Application shall file a copy of the transcript with the Court at least 10 days before the hearing of the Application or the date set for trial whichever comes first in the case of the applicant and 5 days in the case of the respondent or intervener.

The applicant shall file with the Clerk’s office a written brief, along with an electronic version, at least 10 days before the hearing of the Application. The responding party, including any intervener, shall file with the Clerk’s office a written brief, along with an electronic version, and a list of materials to be used at the hearing, at least 5 days before the hearing of the Application. A party shall also provide a written copy of their brief to the opposite party within the same time periods.
The pre-hearing brief shall contain in consecutively numbered paragraphs:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a succinct outline of the facts the party intends to establish,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a concise statement of the issues to be dealt with by the Court,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a concise statement of the principles of law on which the party relies and citation of relevant statutory provisions and leading authorities,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a concise statement of the relief sought by the party,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Schedule A consisting of a list of authorities in the order referred to in the brief, and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Schedule B consisting of the text of all relevant provisions of Acts and Regulations (or copies of the relevant parts of the Act or Regulation may be filed and served with the brief).

Section.Text: An Application shall be heard and determined by a judge of the Court in the judicial district in which the proceeding is being or is to be held.

Subsection.Text: Evidence on an Application may be given by affidavit in Form 2 and in accordance with Rule 3.06, unless the Criminal Code, or other applicable statute provides otherwise.
The affidavits on which an Application is founded shall be served with the Notice of Application and shall be filed in the Clerk’s office.
All affidavits to be used at the hearing in opposition to an Application or in reply shall be served on all the parties and filed in the Clerk’s office, no later than 15 days before the hearing.

Subject to the Criminal Code or any other applicable statute or rule of law, with leave of the presiding judge a witness may be examined or cross-examined upon the hearing of an Application and an affiant may be examined or cross-examined with respect to his or her affidavit and nothing in these rules shall be construed to affect the authority of a judge hearing an Application to receive evidence through the examination of witnesses.

A judge, before or upon the hearing of the Application, may dispense with the filing of any transcript(s) or affidavit(s) required by these Rules and act upon a statement of facts agreed upon by the parties.
The judge may, on such terms as he or she considers just, direct that argument on an Application be presented in writing rather than by personal appearance.

The respondent may consent in writing to the relief sought in an Application and a judge, satisfied that the relief sought by the applicant should be granted, may grant the Application without the attendance of the parties.
The applicant must file with the Court a draft order and the respondent’s consent before the Application will be considered by a judge under Rule 5.06 (7).

Section.Text: Where an applicant desires to abandon the Application, the applicant shall serve, in any manner provided by Rule 4, a Notice of Abandonment in Form 5 signed by counsel in the Application or by the applicant, and the Court may thereupon dismiss the Application as abandoned, without the attendance of counsel or the applicant.
An applicant who fails to appear at the hearing of an Application shall be deemed to have wholly abandoned the Application.

Nothing in this Rule shall be interpreted as derogating from the right of a party to make an Application at any point in the trial; but the failure to give timely notice for such an Application may be taken into account by the judge in determining in all the circumstances

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether to hear the Application; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether to hear the Application forthwith; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether to adjourn the trial to hear the Application; and/or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: on what terms the judge will hear the Application.

TitleText.Emphasis: Under subsection 625.1(1) of the Criminal Code

Subsection.Text: Where an accused is to be tried by a Judge without a jury and it appears that the interests of justice would be served by the holding of a pre-trial conference, any of the parties to the proceeding may apply, or the Court on its own may order, that a pre-trial conference be held in order to facilitate discussion of any or all issues relating to that proceeding.

TitleText.Emphasis: Under subsection 625.1(2) of the Criminal Code

Subsection.Text: Where an accused is to be tried by a court composed of a judge and jury, a pre-trial conference shall be held in order to facilitate discussion of any or all issues relating to that proceeding.

A Pre-trial Conference Submission (Form 6) shall be completed by the parties represented by counsel, exchanged between counsel, and filed in the Clerk’s office at least 5 days in advance of the conference.
An accused not represented by counsel is not required to file a Pre-trial Conference Submission.
The proceedings of the pre-trial conference shall be recorded.
In addition to the topics identified in Form 6 (Pre-trial Conference Submission), a judge conducting a pre-trial conference may inquire as to:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the extent of disclosure made by the prosecutor and any initial or further request therefor by an accused or counsel for an accused;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nature and particulars of any Applications to be made at the outset of the proceedings including any

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Application to contest the laying of the indictment or any count thereof,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: Application to stay or otherwise determine the proceedings prior to plea or t he introduction of evidence,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: Application to challenge the sufficiency of the indictment, to order particulars or to amend the indictment or any count thereof,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: Application to sever the trial of any count(s) or accused from the trial(s) of any other accused or count,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: Application concerning the special pleas of autrefois acquit, autrefois convict or pardon,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: Application to determine the fitness of an accused to stand trial;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the simplification of such issues as remain to be contested at the proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility of obtaining admissions and agreements so as to facilitate an expeditious, fair and just determination of the proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated duration of the proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the advisability of fixing a date for the commencement of the proceedings; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter that may assist in promoting a fair, just and expeditious proceeding.

Section.Text: Nothing in these Rules shall be construed or interpreted so as to preclude a judge from conducting additional pre-trial conferences.

This Pre-trial Conference Rule replaces the Rule of the Court of Queen’s Bench of New Brunswick Respecting Pre-Trial Conferences Under Subsection 553.1(2) of the Criminal Code of Canada adopted by a majority of the judges of the Court of Queen’s Bench of New Brunswick on March 17, 1986, Registration SI/86-78, and published in the Canada Gazette, Part II, Vol. 120, No. 12.

Subsection.Text: Where a matter has been set down for trial and it appears to any of the parties to the proceeding that there is a reasonable likelihood that the matter will not proceed on the date scheduled, owing to a lack of preparation or failure on the part of any of the parties to take steps to ensure that the matter proceeds in a timely fashion on the date(s) set or for any other reason, that party shall request the Clerk’s office to schedule a status hearing.
A judge may at any time direct the Clerk’s office to schedule a status hearing.

At a status hearing the judge shall hear the parties on the issue of whether the scheduled dates for the trial of the matter are reasonably likely to be met by the parties and upon conclusion of the hearing the judge shall either confirm the date(s) set for trial or adjourn the trial and/or give directions.
This Rule applies to the provisions of section 527 of the Criminal Code for procuring the attendance of a person who is confined in a prison.
Where the person who is confined is the accused, the Application shall be made by the prosecutor.
Where the person who is confined is a witness, the Application shall be made by the party that plans to call that witness.

The Application shall be ex parte and made as soon as reasonably practicable and sufficiently before attendance is required to ensure that no adjournment of the proceeding will be required for attendance and to provide adequate notice to the authorities holding and transporting the person who is confined and, in any event, except with leave of the Court, an Application shall be made not less than four days before the day attendance is required.
The Application shall be made by Notice of Application in Form 1 and shall address the requirements of section 527 of the Criminal Code.
In all other aspects these Criminal Procedure Rules of the Court of Queen’s Bench apply to any Applications made under section 527 of the Criminal Code.
This Rule applies to the provisions of subsection 698(1) and subsections 699(1) and (2) of the Criminal Code.

Heading.TitleText: For a Person within the Province

Subsection.Text: Under subsections 698(1) and 699(1) of the Criminal Code, a subpoena may be issued by the Clerk under the seal of the Court upon the applicant filing with the Clerk’s office a statement signed by counsel for the applicant or by the applicant personally if not represented by counsel, setting out the name and address of the proposed witness and a summary of the materiality of the evidence likely to be given by the proposed witness.

Heading.TitleText: For a Person outside the Province

Subsection.Text: An Application under paragraph 699(2)(b) of the Criminal Code for the issuance of a subpoena to a person out of the Province of New Brunswick shall be made ex parte to a judge.
The Application shall be by Notice of Application in Form 1 and shall be accompanied by an affidavit of the applicant or on behalf of the applicant deposing:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as to the name and address of the proposed witness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as to the materiality of the evidence likely to be given by the proposed witness; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: as to the necessity of procuring the personal attendance of the witness rather than obtaining that proposed witness’s evidence by other means, including by video-conference or by agreed statement.

Subsection.Text: Counsel who assume the representation of an accused who was either unrepresented or represented by another counsel shall immediately file a notice to that effect with the Clerk’s office and serve a copy of the notice on the prosecutor in accordance with Rule 4.

Counsel of record for an accused shall remain counsel of record for his or her client with all the responsibilities pertaining thereto, until an order removing counsel from the record has been made by a judge or a new counsel has filed a notice in accordance with Rule 8.03 (1).
An Application to be removed as counsel of record shall be by Notice of Application in Form 1 and shall be governed by these Criminal Procedure Rules of the Court of Queen’s Bench.

Heading.TitleText: Rule 9 - Applications for Declarations of Unconstitutionality

Section.Text: This Rule applies to Applications in criminal proceedings:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to declare unconstitutional and of no force and effect, in whole or in part, any enactment of the Parliament of Canada, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to declare unconstitutional and of no force and effect, in whole or in part, any rule or principle of law applicable to criminal proceedings, whether on account of subsection 8(2) or (3) of the Criminal Code or otherwise.

Section.Text: Service of the Notice of Application and all supporting documentary, affidavit and other material intended to be used at the hearing of the Application shall be made on:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the regional office of the Attorney General of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the prosecutor having carriage of the proceeding; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: such other person and on such terms as a judge may order.

Section.Text: Where applicable, the applicant shall comply with the notice requirements of the Judicature Act.
In all other aspects these Criminal Procedure Rules of the Court of Queen’s Bench apply to Applications seeking declarations of unconstitutionality.
Summary Conviction Appeals shall be governed by Rule 64 of the Rules of Court of New Brunswick.

Heading.TitleText: Rule 11 – Applications for Mandamus, Certiorari and Prohibition

Section.Text: Applications for mandamus, certiorari and prohibition shall be governed by Rule 65 of the Rules of Court of New Brunswick.
These Rules apply to criminal proceedings whenever commenced.
